elements.content: Microporous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are promising candidate materials for chemical sensing, but the reproducible fabrication of MOF-based sensors with optimized and stable performances remains a significant challenge. Here, we report the fabrication of MOF optical sensors with steady but tunable optical properties via assembling UiO-66 crystals with controllable sizes and missing-linker defects. The well-defined but tunable microscopic and mesoscopic structural features of MOF sensing components greatly facilitate the optimization of device performance. The UiO-66 crystal-assembled sensors display fast response (2.00 s) and short recovery (3.00 s) to ethanol vapor (one of the analytes we tested). Our systematical investigation indicates that the mesoporous features of sensing components contribute greatly to the enhanced sensitivity (by ∼24.6% to the saturated ethanol vapor), response speed (by ∼42.9%), and recovery speed (by ∼59.7%) of the crystal-assembled sensors in comparison to their dense counterpart. The building crystal sizes show a slight influence on the response speed but profound effects on the sensitivity and recovery performances of sensors. The missing-linker defects have obvious beneficial effects on the desorption kinetics of analyte and can cause a faster recovery of sensors.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of porous crystalline materials that are built by metal ions (or clusters) coordinated to organic ligands, have received great attention in a variety of fields including gas storage, small molecule separation, heterogeneous catalysis, biomedicine, and chemical sensing due to their large internal surface areas, regular pore sizes, and high thermal stability. The sensing application of MOF materials is based on the change in certain of their macroscopic properties, such as mass, strain stress, conductivity, refractive index, visible color, and luminescence, induced by the sorption of guest molecules in their cavities. The integration of MOF materials into the appropriate devices greatly facilitates signal transduction and data acquisition for the pertinent quantitative evaluation of their sensing performances. In the view of the practical application, the device performance should be optimized and be reproducible, which essentially relies on the precise control over the microscopic (such as porosity and defects) and the mesoscopic structural features (such as sizes and morphologies) of the MOF sensing materials. Nevertheless, these features are synthesis- or/and fabrication-dependent and are somewhat uncontrollable in most cases of the demonstrated MOF sensors. As a result, reports on the further optimization of their performances are comparatively few.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of porous crystalline materials that are built by metal ions (or clusters) coordinated to organic ligands, have received great attention in a variety of fields including gas storage, small molecule separation, heterogeneous catalysis, biomedicine, and chemical sensing due to their large internal surface areas, regular pore sizes, and high thermal stability. The sensing application of MOF materials is based on the change in certain of their macroscopic properties, such as mass, strain stress, conductivity, refractive index, visible color, and luminescence, induced by the sorption of guest molecules in their cavities. The integration of MOF materials into the appropriate devices greatly facilitates signal transduction and data acquisition for the pertinent quantitative evaluation of their sensing performances. In the view of the practical application, the device performance should be optimized and be reproducible, which essentially relies on the precise control over the microscopic (such as porosity and defects) and the mesoscopic structural features (such as sizes and morphologies) of the MOF sensing materials. Nevertheless, these features are synthesis- or/and fabrication-dependent and are somewhat uncontrollable in most cases of the demonstrated MOF sensors. As a result, reports on the further optimization of their performances are comparatively few.

elements.content: MOF optical sensors adopt a transduction pathway that is related to the change in refractive index and can be constructed with different structural configurations such as Fabry–Pérot thin films, one-dimensional (1D) Bragg stacks, two-dimensional (2D) gratings, three-dimensional (3D) colloidal crystals, optical fibers, and photonic microring resonators to generate the refractive index-dependent optical signals in the response to analytes. Commonly, the preparation of MOF films is integral to the whole fabrication of these devices. MOF materials can be processed as thin films via either in situ growth or assembling the presynthesized framework crystals on an appropriate substrate. The former usually yields dense films, whereas the latter produces mesoporous ones. It should also be noted that the as-synthesized MOF samples indeed differ in their pore structures to some extent due to the formation of defects of various types (such as linkers or/and cluster vacancies) during their crystallization. Although these microscopic and mesoscopic structural features have proved to have profound effects on the adsorption capacities of MOF materials as well as the kinetics of molecule diffusion within their frameworks, they have received less attention in the performance evaluation of MOF optical sensors previously reported.

elements.content: Here, we report a reliable strategy that enables the large-scale fabrication of MOF sensors with steady but tunable optical properties and thus facilitates the systematical optimization of device performance. Our strategy is based on the integration of the MOF crystals with the well-controlled microscopic and mesoscopic structural features into the Fabry–Pérot thin-film sensors (). UiO-66, a zirconium-carboxylate MOF (Zr6O4(OH)4(BDC)6, BDC = terephthalic acid), was chosen as the sensing material due to its excellent chemical robustness and thermal stability. More importantly, monodisperse UiO-66 octahedral crystals with tunable sizes and missing-linker defects can be synthesized on a large scale and subsequently assembled into the monolayer films reproducibly. With the rational selection of sensing signals, the effects of the building crystal sizes, the missing-linker defects, and the intercrystal mesoporous structures on the sensitivity, response speed, and recovery speed of sensors were investigated systematically. By optimizing the sizes and defect numbers of building crystals, MOF sensors with fast response (2.00 s) and rapid recovery (3.00 s) (for the saturated ethanol vapor, one of the analytes we tested) were constructed. Our results show that the presence of the intercrystal mesopores in the crystal-assembled sensors (CSs) can effectively improve the sensitivity, response speed, and recovery speed by ∼24.6, ∼42.9, and ∼61.3%, respectively, in comparison to their counterpart configured with a dense MOF film. The building crystal sizes and defect numbers have profound comprehensive effects on the sensitivity and recovery time of CSs to the extent of 120.8 and 78.6%, respectively.

elements.content: UiO-66 crystals were synthesized with acetic acid as a modulator according to established methods. Especially, the base/acid comodulated synthesis allows for the large-scale production of monodisperse UiO-66 octahedral microcrystals with tunable sizes and missing-linker defects. The average sizes and defect numbers (expressed as deficient values of BDC linkers per Zr6 of crystal samples) of MOF crystals were evaluated based on scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements (Figure S1) and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (Figure S2), respectively. Seven crystal samples with sizes in the range of 380–1057 nm and defect numbers of 0.15–0.49 (Table S1) were used for the construction of MOF sensors. The surface of the as-synthesized MOF crystals was modified with the amphiphilic poly­(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) to facilitate their dispersion in ethanol. The PVP-functionalized crystals were subsequently assembled into a dense monolayer at the air/water interface by a modified Langmuir–Blodgett (LB) technique. To construct reflection optical devices, the assembled monolayer was further transferred and formed an MOF film onto a flat silicon substrate (). Theoretically, a single batch of the crystal product (∼150 mg) can yield monolayers with the total area of more than 1270 cm2 (Figure S5), which is nearly 400 times as large as that of a typical sensor (3.0 × 1.1 cm2). As revealed by SEM measurements, the silicon-supported MOF film consists of a layer of closely packed octahedral crystals that contact the platform with their {111} facets (a). The narrow size distribution of crystals and their oriented arrangements on the flat platform render the assembled MOF film a uniform thickness, which can be further increased through programming by forming multilayer structures via the layer-by-layer transfer of monolayers (b) or tuned flexibly by the sizes of building crystals (Figure S6). The overall oriented nature of the assembled MOF films was confirmed by the out-plane X-ray diffraction measurements, where only (111), (222), (333), (444), and (555) reflections were observed as expected (c).

The PVP-functionalized crystals were subsequently assembled into a dense monolayer at the air/water interface by a modified Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) technique. To construct reflection optical devices, the assembled monolayer was further transferred and formed an MOF film onto a flat silicon substrate (). Theoretically, a single batch of the crystal product (~150 mg) can yield monolayers with the total area of more than 1270 cm2 (Figure S5), which is nearly 400 times as large as that of a typical sensor (3.0 × 1.1 cm2). elements.content: These sensors present the perceived colors as the consequence of optical interference in the MOF films deposited on the silicon substrate (a and S7). At normal incidence, the wavelengths (λ) of the reflection interference peaks are given by m λ = 2 nL where m is an integer, n is the refractive index, and L is the thickness of MOF film. Thus, the optical properties of sensors are sensitive to these parameters as manifested by their reflection spectra. As L increases, more interference peaks appear in the reflection spectra within a given wavelength range (325–600 nm), which corresponds to the increase of m, whereas the reflectance (R) decreases dramatically due to the enhanced adsorption and scattering (Figure S8). Accordingly, given their relatively high R optical signal/noise ratio, we will focus on the single-monolayer crystal sensors in the following studies and briefly name them CS y/x according to the size (y) and defect number (x) of their UiO-66 building crystals (for example, CS468/0.26).

elements.content: It should be noted that n of the assembled MOF-crystal films is a volume-weighted average of refractive indices for the crystal framework (n fram), intracrystal micropore (n micro), and intercrystal mesopore (n meso)­ n = f f r a m n f r a m 2 + f m i c r o n m i c r o 2 + f m e s o n m e s o 2 The ratio of volume fractions of MOF framework (f fram) and micropore (f micro) is related to the pore volume of MOF materials, which is determined ideally by the crystal topography but indeed is also influenced by the crystal defects (such as linkers or/and cluster vacancies) existing commonly in the as-synthesized product. As a result, the linker-deficient UiO-66 crystals (with defect numbers of 0.15–0.49) used in this work show the increased pore volumes (0.465–0.483 cm3/g, see Table S1) relative to that of a perfect one (0.426 cm3/g). However, the variation (∼3.9%) of pore volume of MOF crystals in CSs has a relatively slight effect (<2%) on the overall refractive index of MOF films and thus the reflection spectra of sensors. In contrast to the synthesis-dependent f fram/f micro ratio, the volume fraction of intercrystal mesopore (f meso) relies on the assembling and transfer processes of crystal monolayers during device fabrication. To evaluate the effect of these processes on f meso, four sensors consisting of the same batch of UiO-66 crystals were fabricated individually under the identical conditions. As shown in b, their reflection spectra display similar interference peaks and reflectance, which suggests that the crystal assembly strategy enables the reproducible fabrication of MOF sensors with stable optical properties.

elements.content: One of the keys for MOFs as optical sensors to chemical vapors is the tunability of n, or more specifically n micro. Adsorption of any polarizable molecule (with a refractive index larger than 1) by MOFs will displace vacuum within the microporous framework and increase the overall refractive index. This will result in red shifts of the interference peaks and the change of reflectance at a given wavelength. a shows the reflection spectra of CS468/0.26 recorded on exposure to the saturated vapors of methanol, ethanol, acetone, n-hexane, and cyclohexane. Obviously, the sensor is responsive to all of the tested analytes with the evident red shifts of interference peaks (with nitrogen as control). However, the extents of shifts do not follow the trend of analyte refractive indices and instead decrease sequentially for methanol (20.5 nm), ethanol (20.0 nm), acetone (19.5 nm), n-hexane (16.5 nm), and cyclohexane (15.0 nm), whereas their refractive indices increase in the same order (b and Table S3). Since the overall n of MOF sensors is sensitive to both the refractive index of the analyte and its volume fraction, the above results can be attributed to the difference in the adsorption capacities of UiO-66 for these investigated analytes (Figure S9). In addition, it should be noted that the sterically more demanding cyclohexane (6.2 Å) also triggers a moderate response, indicating that this molecule can diffuse through the relatively small pore aperture of UiO-66 (6 Å) due to framework flexibility or/and the presence of missing-linker defects in MOF crystals.

elements.content: For the reflection optical sensors, both the wavelength shift (Δλ) of a selected interference peak and the reflectance change (ΔR) at a given wavelength induced by the analyte sorption can be used as the sensing signals. To achieve high sensitivity for sensors in the latter case, we chose the wavelength with the maximum |ΔR| in the range of 325–500 nm, which was determined by subtracting the spectrum for nitrogen from that for an analyte at saturated pressure (a). Subsequently, Δλ and ΔR were normalized and plotted as the function of relative pressure of analytes, respectively, to establish the optical adsorption isotherms. b shows the respective isotherms derived from the Δλ and ΔR responses of CS468/0.26 to ethanol vapor of various concentrations. Both of them display similarly the steep increase in ethanol uptake at a low relative pressure (<0.1) and the saturation at 0.4–0.6. Meanwhile, minor deviations between them were also observed in the relative pressure range of 0.2–0.6. Given that reflectance was acquired directly by the spectrometer, whereas the wavelength of interference peaks had to be determined manually based on the reflection spectra in our work, the above deviations can be attributed presumably to the inevitable personal errors in the latter determination. Therefore, as far as data acquisition is concerned, ΔR is preferable to Δλ to be used as signals for the quantitative and dynamic study of sensing performances. c shows the normalized ΔR responses of CS468/0.26 recorded on alternate exposure to nitrogen control and to ethanol at saturated pressure. Obviously, the sensor can response reversibly to the ethanol analyte. The dynamic study also provides more in-depth information about the quantitative determination of the response time and recovery time of sensors (d). Commonly, the MOF sensors display fast response (2.00 s for CS468/0.26 to ethanol) and the relatively slow recovery (6.00 s, correspondingly), suggesting more kinetically favorable adsorption of ethanol than nitrogen in UiO-66.

elements.content: The effects of sizes and defect numbers of UiO-66 building crystals on the sensitivity, response speed, and recovery speed of sensors were further investigated. Their sensitivity was evaluated by the maximum |ΔR| of sensors in the wavelength range of 325–500 nm on exposure to ethanol at saturated pressure (Figure S11). As shown in a, the maximum |ΔR| values are 22.34, 18.78, 18.71, 18.53, 15.26, 12.78, and 10.12% for CS380/0.49, CS466/0.19, CS468/0.26, CS506/0.26, CS641/0.15, CS755/0.27, and CS1057/0.41, respectively, indicating that the increase of the size of building crystals lowers the sensitivity due to the decrease in reflectance signals of sensors as discussed above. Based on the reflectance resolution of our spectrometer (3σ = 0.10%) and ΔR at the relative pressure of 0.05, the potential detection limit to ethanol was estimated as 33 ppm for CS380/0.49. As revealed by the dynamic studies (Figures S14–19 and Table S4), all CSs show fast response to ethanol. Their response times (2.00–2.50 s) seem to increase roughly with the sizes of building crystals, but further analysis was frustrated by the data acquisition speed (2 spectra per second). In contrast, CSs display the relatively long recovery times (3.00–14.00 s), which basically decrease as downsizing the MOF crystals except for CS466/0.19 and CS641/0.15. By determining the first moment of an experimental recovery curve via integration, the time constant (τ) for desorption of ethanol molecules in UiO-66 frameworks could be obtained. For spherical particles, the time constant could be described by τ = r 2 15 D + r 3 α where r, D, and α are the crystal radius (half of the crystal sizes), the intracrystal diffusivity, and the surface permeability of MOF crystals, respectively. Assuming the identical D and α for ethanol molecules desorption in MOF crystals with defect numbers of 0.26 and 0.27, the time constants for CS468/0.26, CS506/0.26, and CS755/0.27 were fitted as the function of crystal sizes according to (b). This yielded D of 5.01 × 10–14 m2 s–1 and α of 7.46 × 10–8 m s–1 for the ethanol desorption in these MOF crystals. elements.content: To evaluate the effects of the mesoporous structures in MOF films on the sensing performances, a sensor (DS) configured with a dense UiO-66 film, which was fabricated by the solvothermal growth method, was used for comparison. As shown in a, the deposited MOF film in DS possesses an intergrown surface morphology and a uniform thickness of ∼462 nm that is close to the size of building crystals in CS468/0.26. The TGA results indicate that the MOF material in DS bears more missing-linker defects (x = 0.50) than that in CS468/0.26 (Figure S21). The nitrogen sorption measurements at 77 K (Figure S22a) reveal the absence of 0.92 nm micropore but the presence of a larger one (1.56 nm) in the MOF of DS, which are not observed in that of CS468/0.26 (b) and can be attributed to the increased defect number (0.50) in the former according to previous reports. Nevertheless, the dense MOF film in DS has a higher n than that of the mesoporous sensing film of CS468/0.26 as indicated by its red-shifted interference peaks (Figure S23). On exposure to the saturated ethanol vapor, the DS shows a small maximum |ΔR| (15.02%) relative to that of CS468/0.26 (18.71% as indicated in a), suggesting the lower sensitivity of the former. The ΔR-derived optical adsorption isotherm of DS for ethanol deviates slightly from that of CS468/0.26 in the relative pressure range of 0.25–0.45 (c). Interestingly, the similar deviation was also observed for their normalized nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K in the relative pressure range of 0.01–0.3 (Figure S22b), which could be attributed to the presence of larger micropores in MOF of DS. The dynamic sensing studies (to ethanol analyte at saturated pressure) reveal the much slower response (3.50 s) and recovery (15.50 s) of DS462/0.50 (d) as compared to those of CS468/0.26 (2.00 and 6.00 s, respectively, see above). If only defect number was taken into account, this observation would apparently be in contradiction with the above statement that high defect number results in faster response and recovery. Accordingly, the enhanced response and recovery performances of CS468/0.26 could be attributed to the intercrystal mesoporous structures in the sensing MOF films that facilitate greatly the diffusion of analyte molecules.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated the fabrication of MOF optical sensors based on assembling of UiO-66 crystals with controllable sizes and missing-linker defects. These MOF-crystal-assembled sensors show steady but tunable optical properties and can be fabricated reproducibly on a large scale. The sensor configuration was optimized in the form of single-monolayer crystals for the performance evaluation with the rational selection of reflectance change as sensing signals. Our results show that the mesoporous features render the crystal-assembled sensors higher sensitivity and faster response and recovery in comparison to their counterparts configured with a dense MOF film. The sensitivity of sensors is basically dependent on their building crystal sizes and increases with the decrease of crystal sizes. The recovery performance of sensors was strongly influenced by both the sizes and missing-linker defects of building crystals and can be enhanced by decreasing the crystal sizes and increasing the (missing-linker) defects. With the continuous progress in the controlled synthesis of MOF materials, we believe that the crystal-assembling strategy will provide a reliable route to constructing MOF devices of other framework materials with tunable microscopic and mesoscopic structural features.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated the fabrication of MOF optical sensors based on assembling of UiO-66 crystals with controllable sizes and missing-linker defects. These MOF-crystal-assembled sensors show steady but tunable optical properties and can be fabricated reproducibly on a large scale. The sensor configuration was optimized in the form of single-monolayer crystals for the performance evaluation with the rational selection of reflectance change as sensing signals. Our results show that the mesoporous features render the crystal-assembled sensors higher sensitivity and faster response and recovery in comparison to their counterparts configured with a dense MOF film. The sensitivity of sensors is basically dependent on their building crystal sizes and increases with the decrease of crystal sizes. The recovery performance of sensors was strongly influenced by both the sizes and missing-linker defects of building crystals and can be enhanced by decreasing the crystal sizes and increasing the (missing-linker) defects. With the continuous progress in the controlled synthesis of MOF materials, we believe that the crystal-assembling strategy will provide a reliable route to constructing MOF devices of other framework materials with tunable microscopic and mesoscopic structural features.

elements.content: The monodisperse UiO-66 were synthesized according to the reported methods. Briefly, for 380 nm crystals, a mixture of ZrCl4 (0.08 mmol) and terephthalic acid (BDC, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) containing acetic acid (24 mmol) in a 9 dram borosilicate glass vial. The vial was capped and placed at 120 °C for 24 h. For crystals with sizes of 466–1057 nm, 140 mL of DMF solution containing BDC (0.6 mmol), trimethylamine (TEA, 0–0.9 mmol), and acetic acid (360 mmol) was stirred at room temperature for 10 min and then heated to 120 °C. After 10 mL of DMF solution of ZrCl4 (0.6 mmol) was added, the mixture was allowed to react at 120 °C for another 6 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed several times with DMF and methanol sequentially, and soaked in methanol for three days with replacing the soaking solvent every 12 h. To functionalize their surface, the MOF crystals (50 mg) were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol solution of poly­(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, 5 wt %) and the suspension was shaken on a vortex oscillator overnight. Finally, the crystals were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and redispersed in 1.5 mL of ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and PVP-Modification of UiO-66 Crystals

The monodisperse UiO-66 were synthesized according to the reported methods. Briefly, for 380 nm crystals, a mixture of ZrCl4 (0.08 mmol) and terephthalic acid (BDC, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) containing acetic acid (24 mmol) in a 9 dram borosilicate glass vial. The vial was capped and placed at 120 °C for 24 h. For crystals with sizes of 466-1057 nm, 140 mL of DMF solution containing BDC (0.6 mmol), trimethylamine (TEA, 0-0.9 mmol), and acetic acid (360 mmol) was stirred at room temperature for 10 min and then heated to 120 °C. After 10 mL of DMF solution of ZrCl4 (0.6 mmol) was added, the mixture was allowed to react at 120 °C for another 6 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed several times with DMF and methanol sequentially, and soaked in methanol for three days with replacing the soaking solvent every 12 h. To functionalize their surface, the MOF crystals (50 mg) were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol solution of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, 5 wt %) and the suspension was shaken on a vortex oscillator overnight. Finally, the crystals were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and redispersed in 1.5 mL of ethanol.

elements.content: A precleaned glass slide (1.2 × 7.2 cm2) was leaned against the rim of a Petri dish (9 cm in diameter), and DI water was added to the Petri dish. A suspension of the PVP-modified UiO-66 crystals (100 μL) was dropped on the glass slide and spread quickly on the water surface. Subsequently, a few drops of aqueous solution of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS, 2 wt %) were added to condense the UiO-66 crystals so that a dense monolayer was formed on the water surface. Finally, the monolayer was transferred onto a pretreated silicon substrate and dried under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of UiO-66 Crystal-Assembled Sensors

A precleaned glass slide (1.2 × 7.2 cm2) was leaned against the rim of a Petri dish (9 cm in diameter), and DI water was added to the Petri dish. A suspension of the PVP-modified UiO-66 crystals (100 μL) was dropped on the glass slide and spread quickly on the water surface. Subsequently, a few drops of aqueous solution of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS, 2 wt %) were added to condense the UiO-66 crystals so that a dense monolayer was formed on the water surface. Finally, the monolayer was transferred onto a pretreated silicon substrate and dried under ambient conditions.

elements.content: The silicon-supported UiO-66 sensors were fixed inside a home-built PMMA flow cell (0.4 × 1.5 × 3.0 cm3) with an adhered glass window. The saturated vapors of analytes (methanol, ethanol, acetone, n-hexane, and cyclohexane) were produced by bubbling nitrogen through a glass vessel containing the corresponding solvents. A flow of pure nitrogen gas (100 sccm) was used as the control and initially introduced to the sample cell. Subsequently, the flow was changed to the mixture of pure nitrogen and a saturated analyte vapor at various ratios and at a total flow rate of 100 sccm. The reflection spectra of sensors were monitored in real time and acquired at 500 ms intervals using a commercial optical fiber spectrometer (Maya 2000 Pro, Ocean Optics) at room temperature and 1 bar on exposure to the control or analyte vapors. The distance between the probe of the spectrometer and the sensor surface was ∼3 mm and kept constant in all sensing measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor Sensing Measurements

The silicon-supported UiO-66 sensors were fixed inside a home-built PMMA flow cell (0.4 × 1.5 × 3.0 cm3) with an adhered glass window. The saturated vapors of analytes (methanol, ethanol, acetone, n-hexane, and cyclohexane) were produced by bubbling nitrogen through a glass vessel containing the corresponding solvents. A flow of pure nitrogen gas (100 sccm) was used as the control and initially introduced to the sample cell. Subsequently, the flow was changed to the mixture of pure nitrogen and a saturated analyte vapor at various ratios and at a total flow rate of 100 sccm. The reflection spectra of sensors were monitored in real time and acquired at 500 ms intervals using a commercial optical fiber spectrometer (Maya 2000 Pro, Ocean Optics) at room temperature and 1 bar on exposure to the control or analyte vapors. The distance between the probe of the spectrometer and the sensor surface was ~3 mm and kept constant in all sensing measurements.
